Whey and soy protein-based hydrogels and nano-hydrogels as bioactive delivery systems
Arash Abaeea, Mehdi Mohammadianb, Seid Mahdi Jafaria,∗
a Department of Food Materials and Process Design Engineering, Gorgan University of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources, Gorgan, Iran b Department of Food Science and Engineering, University College of Agriculture and Natural Resources, University of Tehran, Karaj, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Hydrogels Nano-gels Globular proteins Delivery systems Whey proteins Soy proteins
A B S T R A C T
Background: Bioactive molecules are mostly amenable to degradation at processing, storage, and harsh digestion conditions. Hence, high-throughput encapsulation bodies must be designed in a way to protect them from destructive circumstances and to enhance their bioavailability. Scope and approach: This review article focuses on versatile mechanisms for gelation of globular proteins and highlights the current studies on whey and soy protein hydrogels as two key animal and herbal proteins used in fabricating coating materials. Moreover, different categories of hydrogels, such as aerated hydrogels, hydrogels made from aggregated forms of proteins, hydrogels originated from food-grade materials, and hydrogels with nano scale dimensions are discussed. Key findings and conclusions: The gelation and particulation method have dramatic effects on the liberation features as well as the bioactivity of the wrapped ingredients. Therefore, different approaches are needed to be considered in order to increase the bioavailability of nutraceuticals and drugs accommodated within protein hydrogels. Accordingly, there is a growing trend for developing innovative modes of gelation and immobilizing bioactive materials into the hydrogel network.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Delivery systems are engineered as a means to retain the sensitive compounds from degradation against food processing operations, digestive enzymes plus unfavorable environmental conditions (e.g., oxidation, temperature, pH, and light), as well as for site-specific gastrointestinal delivery and controlled release of water-loving and waterfearing nutraceuticals (Faridi Esfanjani & Jafari, 2016; Katouzian & Jafari, 2016). Delivery systems can be classified to lipidbased networks (e.g., conventional emulsions, micro- and nanoemulsions, multiple emulsions, liposomes, solid lipid nanoparticles, and nano-structured lipid carriers), biopolymer-based systems (e.g., individual carbohydrate and protein carriers and their complexes), nature-inspired systems (e.g., caseins, cyclodextrins, and amylose helixes), and specialized equipment-based systems (e.g., electrospinning and electrospraying, and nano-spray dryer) (Jafari, 2017a,b). Among these systems, protein-based hydrogels are especially welcomed from different sectors due to their outstanding properties, such as high nutritional value, excellent functional properties, amphiphilic nature, biocompatibility, biodegradability, and lower toxicity in comparison with synthetic polymers (Snyders et al., 2007).
There are three gel-based delivery vehicles: hydrogels, organogels, and bigels. Hydrogels are three-dimensional solid networks fabricated by physically or chemically cross-linked hydrophilic polymeric structures that can entangle a lot of water or other biological liquid inside their network (Iemma et al., 2006). Hydrogels can be formulated in different physical states including microparticles, nanoparticles, coatings, and films (Ahmed, 2015; Hoare & Kohane, 2008). An organogel or oleogel is a thermoreversible semi-solid system composed of a liquid organic phase within a three-dimensional, cross-linked network (Vintiloiu & Leroux, 2008). Self-assembly is the main mechanism for the formation of the gel network in organogels in which mostly low molecular weight compounds are capable of gelling organic solvents (Marangoni & Garti, 2015; Vintiloiu & Leroux, 2008). Bigels are other rapidly expanding delivery systems which are formulated via the combination of an organogel with a hydrogel at relatively high shear rates. With respect to their structure, bigels have the characteristics of both hydrogels and organogel and have spawning novel applications in the delivery of bioactive compounds (Lupi et al., 2015, 2016; Sagiri et al., 2015; Singh et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 2. Preparation and formation of hydrogels
sections.text:
Biopolymer-derived hydrogels have recently captured considerable attention as promising delivery practices for nutraceuticals and drugs. Natural carbohydrates and proteins are proper nominees for engineering delivery systems owing to their ability for gelation, amenability to modifications, structural diversity, biodegradability, and biocompatibility (Mokhtari, Jafari, & Assadpour, 2017). Food globular proteins, owing to their aggregation and gelation properties, can wrap bioactive compounds inside their network and are reliable delivery systems due to their inherent biocompatibility, biodegradability, high nutritional value, and tunable swelling and liberation characteristics (Chen, Remondetto, & Subirade, 2006).
Globular proteins are able to produce heat and cold-set gels (Zhang, Zhang, Chen, Tong, &McClements, 2015). Heating of protein aqueous solutions triggers molecular unfolding and disruption of proteins, thereby leading to exposure of hydrophobic patches as well as to formation of disulfide bonds. Finally, heat-set gels will be formed by the aggregation of the unfolded protein moieties along with the participation of intermolecular β-sheet architectures (Caillard, Remondetto, Mateescu, & Subirade, 2008; Oztop, McCarthy, McCarthy, & Rosenberg, 2014). In the case of whey protein heat-induced gels, gel network is basically formed through covalent bonds (inter- and intramolecular disulfide bonds) and a broad array of non-covalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding, ionic, and hydrophobic interactions (Oztop, McCarthy, McCarthy, & Rosenberg, 2012; Oztop et al., 2014). On the contrary, globular proteins yield gels via the cold-gelation approach. Having a uniform architecture, high strength, and the ability to gel at ambient temperatures, cold-set gels are unique candidates for designing functional foods in which heat sensitive nutraceuticals are preserved (Nicolai, Britten, & Schmitt, 2011; Martin & De Jong, 2012a; Veerman, Baptist, Sagis, & van der Linden, 2003). It is important to bear in mind that the applications of heat-set gels are limited to the formulations that do not contain heat-sensitive bioactive ingredients due to the requirement of heat treatment for these types of hydrogels (Chen et al., 2006).
Cold-set gelation of food globular proteins occurs in two stages, which initiates by heating the protein solution at neutral pH (above isoelectric point) below the protein gelling extent and at low ionic strength steering the reaction to denaturation and imperfect unfolding of proteins. This follows by acidification to reach the isoelectric pH of protein (acid-induced cold gelation) or supplementation with salts (saltinduced cold gelation) so that the inter-protein repulsion is lowered (mono, di and polyvalent cations) and/or to generate cross-linkages (only di and polyvalent cations) among protein clusters (Kuhn, Cavallieri, & Da Cunha, 2010). CaCl2 and NaCl are applied to the cold gelation of globular proteins (Kuhn, Cavallieri, & Da Cunha, 2011). Alternative cations, such as Fe2+ (Martin & De Jong, 2012a; Remondetto, Paquin, & Subirade, 2002) and Mg2+ (da Silva, Delgado & Goncalves, 2010) also have been utilized to fabricate whey protein cold-set gels with improved nutritional value and functionality. One main advantage of cold-induced gelation over other methods is the exposure of different functional groups within the protein molecules as a result of denaturation which can create various interactions between bioactive ingredient and polypeptide chains such as hydrogen-bonding, electrostatic, and hydrophobic interactions. These newly-formed bonds between bioactive compounds and proteins can be exploited to design targeted delivery systems (Chen et al., 2006). Moreover, a greater control over the resulting shape, structure and texture of the produced gel is allowed by the cold-induced approach of gelation (Egan, O'Riordan, O'Sullivan, & Jacquier, 2014).
Hydrogels prepared from globular proteins such as whey proteins, vegetable globulins, soy proteins, egg white proteins, pea proteins, wheat proteins plus other origins are discussed in detail within the literature. In addition, the physicochemical and industrial significance hydrogels prepared from animal and herbal resources (i.e., whey and soy proteins) and their role in the delivery of nutraceuticals and
bioactive ingredients such as vitamins, minerals, drugs, etc., have been reviewed brilliantly.

sections.heading: 2.1. Nano-scale hydrogels as delivery systems
sections.text:
According to the recent advancements in nanotechnology, scholars are eager to apply nanotechnology in designing delivery systems for confinement, protection, and site-specific liberation of bioactive materials (Jafari &McClements, 2017; Joye, Davidov-Pardo, &McClements, 2014). Delivery of drugs and nutraceuticals by the means of nanotechnology, results in the improvement of their bioavailability as well as increasing their residence time in the gastrointestinal tract (Ghasemi, Jafari, Assadpour, & Khomeiri, 2017). One striking feature of nanocarriers is their ability to permeate into the living tissues and enter the epithelial cell lining fenestration and to arrive at the intended cells. Among the distinctive natural or synthetic polymer-based nanoparticulate entities employed in the food industry, protein-based nanohydrogels have demonstrated practical applications due to their nontoxicity, biodegradability, and miniscule size with a large interior network for multivalent bioconjugation, which offers enough space for entrapment of functional components (Chen et al., 2006). Protein gelation has been suggested for the fabrication of micron- (below 100 μm) and nano-sized (below about 0.1 μm) fragments (Stokes, 2012). For instance, nanogels can be formulated by heating a uniform solution of soy proteins (Chen, Lin, Sun, & Zhao, 2014) or by heating of microemulsified whey protein solutions (Zhang & Zhong, 2010).
Ding and Yao (2013) fabricated soy protein/soy polysaccharide complex nanogels to convey folic acid to the intestine. Nanogels were made through electrostatic binding of soy proteins with soy polysaccharides and folic acid at pH = 4.0 and the denaturation of proteins via thermal processing. It was suggested that soy protein/soy polysaccharide nanogels are able to preserve folic acid against harsh storage and processing situations in the preparation of food and beverage formulations. Moreover, Feng et al. (2015) developed soy β-conglycinin−dextran core−shell nanogels via the Maillard reaction followed by a self-assembly procedure. Dextran is able to impart steric hindrance at the shell of the nanoparticles, thereby stabilizing the nanoparticles. Authors claimed that these nanoparticles have the application for the delivery of water-insoluble molecules owing to the hydrophobic attraction between β-conglycinins and bioactive compounds.
In another study, Sadeghi, Madadlou, and Yarmand (2014) fabricated nutraceutical-carrying whey protein nanoparticles by microemulsification-cold gelation mode. Aqueous extract of date palm pit was entrapped in a water-in-oil microemulsion containing heat-degraded whey proteins and glucono delta-lactone (GDL) in its aqueous state. As a result, at the isoelectric pH of whey proteins, the nanodroplets formed gel structure once the hydrolysis of GDL took place.

sections.heading: 3. Factors affecting formation of globular protein hydrogels
sections.text: Several techniques have been employed to fabricate hydrogels from biopolymers including cold and heat gelation strategies (Chen et al., 2006). From another perspective, food protein gelation procedures can be divided into three classes: physical (heat, high pressure), chemical (pH, ionic), and biochemical (enzymatic action) techniques (Norton, Espinosa, Watson, Spyropoulos, & Norton, 2015). Gelation plus the matrix and textural attributes of formulated food globular proteinbased hydrogels can be regulated through different factors, such as type of ion, temperature, pH, ionic strength and extent of added ion and chemical bonding agents used for gelation (Nicolai et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 3.1. Type and concentration of ions
sections.text:
The ultimate gel architecture depends on the added amount of ions added to the heat denatured protein solutions (Fig. 1); hydrogels with fine-stranded (consisted of cross-linked flexible strands) are formed as a
result of low salt levels along with the robust electrostatic repulsion. On the other hand, particulate gels (consisted of stochastic associated micron-sized spheres) are produced whenever the consumed level of ions is high (Nicolai & Durand, 2013) as it was reported for soy (Maltais, Remondetto, & Subirade, 2009) and whey proteins (Kuhn et al., 2010).
Lefevre and Subirade (2000) studied the differences between finestranded and particulate β-lactoglobulin gels at a molecular level using Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy. The positions of aggregated components in the FTIR spectra were different for these two types of gels; in the wavenumber range of 1620–1623 cm−1 for particulate gels and in the range of 1613–1619 cm−1 for fine-stranded counterpart. Accordingly, they concluded that the hydrogen bonds for β-lactoglobulin particulate gel aggregates are weaker than for finestranded ones. It can be due to the higher unfolding of proteins during the formation of fine-stranded cold-set gels which results in a closer alignment of the polypeptide chains and subsequently generation of stronger hydrogen bonds for these types of β-lactoglobulin cold-set hydrogels. The formation mechanisms of fine-stranded and particulate gels are presented in Fig. 2.
In addition to the concentration, the class of the utilized ions is also important for the gelation process; mono and di or polyvalent cations can generate hydrogels by charge screening effects; di or polyvalent cations can also establish ion-bridging or cross-linking phenomena to from gels (Nicolai et al., 2011). Kuhn et al. (2010) observed that WPI hydrogels generated by CaCl2 addition were firmer, more elastic, and more opaque in comparison with those prepared by addition of NaCl. Nevertheless, these hydrogels (CaCl2-induced) demonstrated a lower water holding capacity because of their more compact matrix. Ordinarily, divalent cations form bridges between protein chains and entangle water inside the formed pores, while monovalent salts attract the
water molecules through the generation of hydration layers (Kuhn et al., 2010). The analysis of mono (NaCl) and divalent (CaCl2) cations at concentration of 150 mM on the properties of whey protein isolateflaxseed gum cold-set gels, Kuhn et al. (2011) reported that calciuminduced gels were stable, stronger and capable of retaining more water plus lower deformability in comparison with NaCl-induced counterparts. In the case of cations with same number of valence electrons, ionic radius plays a chief role in the final attributes of the formulated cold-set gel; the greater the ionic radius, the lower is the surface charge density and thus fewer interactions are enabled between protein molecules via counter ions (Kundu, Chinchalikar, Das, Aswal, & Kohlbrecher, 2014).
Based on small-angle neutron scattering (SANS) analysis of heated bovine serum albumin, a better gelation was obtained by higher charge density ions in relation to their lower ionic radius (Kundu, Chinchalikar, Das, Aswal, & Kohlbrecher, 2014). Mostly, intermolecular interaction of macromolecules such as proteins are affected by several means via cations (Kundu et al., 2014; Kunz, 2010; Loveday, Su, Rao, & Anema, & Singh, 2012): (1) screening of residue charges such as carboxylate groups which can take place at both low (less than 0.1 M) and higher amounts; (2) The formation of ionic bridges by polyvalent cations which also can happen at low and high ion concentrations and (3) specific ion effects or their competition with proteins and other molecules for bonding with water molecules which is highly favorable at higher concentrations of ions.

sections.heading: 3.2. Covalent cross-linking and gelation of food globular proteins
sections.text:
Owing to the presence of amino and carboxyl groups, poly peptide chains are vulnerable to covalent cross-linking via different routes such
as introduction of transglutaminase (Eissa, Puhl, Kadla, & Khan, 2006), genipin (Guo et al., 2017), glutaraldehyde (Suesca, Dias, Braga, de Sousa, & Fontanilla, 2017), and polycarboxylic acids (Xu, Shen, Xu, & Yang, 2015a; Abaee, Madadlou, & Saboury, 2017).

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Enzyme induced cross-linking
sections.text:
The enzyme transglutaminase catalyzes acyl transfer reaction between peptide-bound glutamine residues as acyl donor and primary amines as acceptor. This enzyme is commonly applied to protein crosslinking in the food sector (Aboumahmoud & Savello, 1990). Protein polymerization with transglutaminase may endow desirable functional properties to proteins (Motoki, Nio, & Takinami, 1984) and enhance the protein stability against gastric condition as well (Monogioudi et al., 2011).
The transglutaminase enzyme has been utilized to enable the gelation process for preparing hydrogels and emulsion gels from soy protein isolate (Song & Zhang, 2008), gelatin (Crescenzi, Francescangeli, & Taglienti, 2002), casein, 11S globulin, and 7S globulin (Nio, Motoki, & Takinami, 1986; Noriki, Motoki, & Takinami, 1985). Furthermore, it has been proved that polymerization with transglutaminase may improve the rheological attributes of gels prepared by this method (Abaee &Madadlou, 2016; Eissa, Bisram, & Khan, 2004). Guo, Zhang, and Yang (2012) used transglutaminase for preparing transparent soy glycinin-dextran sulfate hydrogels. In this method, the partial unfolding of glycinin was acquired by heating 6% protein solution involving dextran sulfate. Next, the microbial transglutaminase was used to cross-link the electrostatically stabled soy glycinin-dextran sulfate networks.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Chemical cross-linkers
sections.text: The typical chemical cross-linkers used for proteins include glutaraldehyde, glyceraldehyde, formaldehyde, genipin, glyoxal, dialdehyde starch, and carbonyldiimidazole. However, most of the current crosslinking agents are not safe and cost-effective (Xu et al., 2015a). Among these cross-linking agents, glutaraldehyde and formaldehyde have been extensively used as two most potent cross-linkers to cross-link proteins. However the aldehyde groups of these agents are toxic for cells and also they could cause environmental pollution. Safe cross-linkers such as genipin and carbodiimides also showed some disadvantages such as low cross-linking efficiency and being expensive (Xu, Shen, Xu, & Yang, 2015b). As a proper alternative, citric acid which is a readily available, generally recognized as safe (GRAS), inexpensive, and nontoxic metabolic product involved in Krebs cycle and occurs naturally in citrus fruits, such as lemon (Franklin & Guhanathan, 2014; Xu et al., 2015b) has been applied for cross-linking of proteins and carbohydrates. In the case of low-temperature alkali-catalyzed wet cross-linking of proteins, carboxyl groups in citric acid react with amino groups in protein through a nucleophilic exchange resulting in the formation of amide agents (Xu et al., 2015a). Bagheri, Yarmand, Madadlou, and Mousavi (2014) cross-linked whey proteins either by the enzyme transglutaminase or citric acid and prepared small and stable particles through desolvating the cross-linked whey proteins. Farjami, Madadlou, and Labbafi (2015) fabricated calcium-induced hydrogels from citric acidcross-linked whey protein microgels. Cross-linking by the aid of citric acid has been tested for other proteins, such as gliadin fibers (Reddy, Li, & Yang, 2008), zein nanoparticles (Xu et al., 2015b), and re-constituted casein fibers (Yang & Reddy, 2012). Freshly, a new gelation method based on citric acid cross-linking of proteins was developed (Abaee et al., 2017). It was observed that extensive cross-linking of whey proteins by citric acid leads to gelation of non-heat-treated whey proteins. Textural and functional properties of citric acid cross-linked gels are tunable and rely on the protein and citric acid concentration, pH, and incubation time.

sections.heading: 3.3. High pressure gelation
sections.text:
High-pressure processing, as a novel technology, has also been used for gelation of food proteins. A treatment with high pressure denatures proteins by rupturing of hydrophobic and electrostatic bonds while heat treatment mainly affects the disruption of hydrogen bonds (Ngarize, Adams, & Howell, 2005). Some advantages were reported for high pressure-induced gelation compared to the heat-induced method of gelation such as producing a softer and smoother texture and hindering browning reactions (Apichartsrangkoon, 2003).
Studying the impact of high pressure on soy protein isolate and its elemental ingredients including 7S and 11S globulins, Molina, Defaye, and Ledward (2002) observed that self-supporting gels were formed by exerting 300–700 MPa pressure on 20% protein solution. It was reported that several factors can regulate the gelation of soy proteins such as protein concentration, pH, ionic strength, plus additives (sugar for example), pressure level, holding time, and process temperature (Alvarez, Ramaswamy, & Ismail, 2008). It was found that both storage and loss moduli of concentrated soy protein matrix (20% protein concentration) were augmented at higher pressures (200–800 MPa). Moreover, greater changes were observed for these moduli at 60 °C compared to 20 °C which was in-line with the denaturation of 7S globulins at higher temperatures (Apichartsrangkoon, 2003). Fertsch, Müller, and Hinrichs (2003) also studied the changes in firmness of pressure-induced whey protein isolate gels (600 MPa, 30 °C) as a function of holding time and rate of pressure release. They suggested that firmness of pressure-induced WPI hydrogels was closely related to the protein denaturation level during pressure introduction. In fact, long pressure release results in denaturation and aggregation of β-lactoglobulin moieties by means of disulfide bonds and gel formation is catalyzed. More amounts of disulfide bonds also were generated at higher pressure holding time; about 70% for 30 min holding at 600 MPa compared to 63.4% for 15 min.
In a study conducted by He, Mu, and Wang (2013) the in vitro digestibility of WPI gels produced via high pressure processing (400 MPa and 30 min) was compared with heat-set ones (80 °C and 30 min). In vitro gastrointestinal digestion assay was performed in the presence of pepsin (pH 1.5, 37 °C, 30 min) and trypsin (pH 7.0, 40 °C, 60 min) depicted a higher digestibility with more and smaller peptides for pressure-induced gels than those formed by heat or native whey protein isolate, probably due to the presence of more soluble disulfide aggregations which investigated by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis analysis. In agreement with these results, Tang and Ma (2009) tested higher amounts of insoluble aggregates in the soy protein isolate blend which was treated with lower levels of pressure (e.g., 200 MPa) by means of size-exclusion chromatography together with multi-angle laser scattering in comparison with the obvious formation of soluble ones at higher pressure levels like 400 or 600 MPa. It seems more efforts need to be made to better understand the application of pressure-induced food protein hydrogels as drug delivery systems.

sections.heading: 4. Soy protein-based hydrogels
sections.text:
Soy proteins, as roughly the main components (about 35–40%) of soy bean (Glycine max) seeds (Nesterenko, Alric, Silvestre, & Durrieu, 2014), comprising 2 key fractions namely: glycinin or 11S globulin and β-conglycinin or 7S globulin. Soy proteins are typically purified in forms of soy protein isolate (over 90% protein content) and concentrate (about 70% protein) for industrial and research areas. Owing to their nutritious nature, low cost, biodegradability, and purposive physicochemical and functional attributes such as gelling, emulsifying, foaming capacity, water binding and fat-absorbing, soy proteins are of great interest in the food area (Caillard et al., 2008). Among the soy protein fractions, aggregation of glycinin contributes to generation of a stiffer gel due to the shaping of more organized structures (Liu, Cui,
Wu, & Liao, 2014). Nonetheless, it was reported that the foaming ability and emulsifying performance of glycinin is lower than β-conglycinin because of its dense network stabilized by disulfide bonds (Nishinari, Fang, Guo, & Phillips, 2014). Some of the major characteristics of soy proteins are illustrated in Fig. 3.
It should also be noted that soy protein-based infant formulas currently comprise about 13% of the total infant formula consumption in the US mainly because of the presence of different amino acids such as acidic, non-polar, and also basic (lysine and arginine) amino acids (Reddy & Yang, 2011). Currently, soy protein-based systems such as hydrogels, emulsions, films, fibers, and micro- and nano-particles are massively employed for efficient delivery of bioactives and nutraceuticals. Moreover, it has been suggested that plant-originated proteins such as soy proteins could be safer delivery systems compared with animal-originated proteins due to the less possibility of transmitting zoonotic diseases (Xu et al., 2015b). However, the low solubility of soy proteins at acidic pH values especially at pH of about 4.8 limits their applications in acidic foods and beverages (Ding & Yao, 2013). Herein, we focus on the hydrogels made from soy proteins as efficient vectors for bioactive molecules. Besides, a brief overview of recent studies on soy protein based hydrogels with the aim of delivering of bioactive components has been presented in Table 1.
Studying the release trend of fluorescein-bearing heat-induced soy protein hydrogels (with 15, 18 and 20% protein concentration), Chien, Chung, and Shah (2014) observed prompt drug liberation for the entire samples with a maximum at 8 h for hydrogel with protein amount of 15%. In addition, the drug release difference between hydrogels with 18% and 20% protein was not considered to be dramatic owing to the identical mechanical and swelling attributes. An acceptable in vitro (seven days) and in vivo (degradation over 3 weeks) biocompatibility was detected for these hydrogels which may find suitable application on wound healing practices. In another analysis Ding and Yao (2013) developed soy protein/soy polysaccharide hydrogels for retention and controlled transfer of folic acid. Folic acid-bearing hydrogels were formulated by stirring (3 h), high-pressure homogenization (600 bar for 2 min), and heat treatment (90 °C for 1 h) at pH 4.0. Folic acid release
trend was analyzed in a phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) medium (pH 7.4) at 37 °C. Release studies demonstrated a quick release for folic acid in PBS due to its solubility in aqueous solutions and low gel-binding tendency. Besides, the extent of folic acid photo-degradation in the gel matrix was only 17% where it was 100%, 33%, and 27% for free folic acid, folic acid + soy polysaccharide and folic acid + soy protein samples, consecutively. On the basis of these observations along with the perfect stability of folic acid/soy protein/soy polysaccharide gel at acidic media, the authors proposed that the prepared gels can be implemented in food beverages in regard to their pH value which is about 3.0. Soy β-conglycinin-dextran gels were also introduced as proper structures to accommodate water-insoluble bioactive compounds due to the hydrophobic interaction between β-conglycinin and these elements (Feng et al., 2015).
Song and Zhang (2009) studied the potential biomedical application of soy protein isolate gels generated via a natural cross-linking agent, genipin which is 10,000 times less cytotoxic than the commonly used chemical cross-linker glutaraldehyde. Drug release behavior of gels was investigated by using the protein-based bovine serum albumin (BSA) within the simulated gastric and intestinal juice. Genipin-cross-linked soy protein isolate gels had a lower BSA release rate in simulated gastric circumstances (pH = 1.2) compared to intestinal conditions (pH = 7.4). The low swelling degree of gels in the acidic media was the cause of this slow release trend. Thus, the naturally cross-linked soy protein gels can be helpful in site-specific intestinal drug delivery. In a research conducted by Caillard, Mateescu, and Subirade (2010) the in vitro release of ionic compounds (amaranth, an anionic model drug and methylene blue, a cationic type) from Maillard-type cross-linked soy protein hydrogels was determined. Hydrogels were prepared by different amounts of glutaraldehyde as a Maillard type cross-linking agent and NaCl as a pre-denaturation element. In the absence of digestive enzymes, no amaranth release was detected in the simulated gastric fluid, whereas after 6 h digestion in the simulated intestinal juice, the amaranth release rate was 35%–50% in terms of the cross-linker concentration. In contrary to amaranth, the methylene blue had a higher release rate in the simulated gastric fluid. In the presence of pepsin, the
release extent of methylene blue increased significantly and reached to 90% after 3 h due to the structure disruption by enzyme, but the amaranth release was dramatically slow in this case. In regard to the simulated intestinal media with pancreatin, the liberation of methylene blue also incremented but not as much of the addition of pepsin. Three hours of digestion in the presence of pancreatin resulted in 85%–95% liberation of amaranth payload. The authors also reported a trivial effect of cross-linker type (glutaraldehyde or NaCl) and concentration on the release profiles of these types of ionic drugs. In general, these chemically cross-linked soy protein hydrogels are promising candidates for the delivery of intended drugs at the stomach and colon sites. Guo et al. (2013) also proposed that the soy protein porous hydrogel prepared by homogenizing and microbial transglutaminase cross-linking as a vehicle for transmitting of nutrients and flavors.
Maltais, Remondetto, and Subirade (2010) manufactured tablets from soy protein filamentous hydrogel by pressing the lyophilized gel and employed them as a riboflavin vectors for stomach and intestinal delivery. Without any digestive proteases, riboflavin liberation from soy protein cold-set hydrogel and its tablet was higher at pH = 7.5 (with swelling mode) than pH = 1.2 (drug-polymer interactions mode). Six hours digestion of hydrogels and tablets with pepsin at simulated gastric fluid had low zero-order release of riboflavin; indeed release reached to 23% for tablets and 13% for hydrogel. These low values of release were attributed to resistant behavior of soy protein matrices to the hydrolysis by pepsin due to the presence of lower amounts of hydrophobic aromatic amino acids which are preferential cleavage site of pepsin in the soy proteins. Yet, 6 h digestion with pancreatin led to the thorough degradation of drug-loaded hydrogels and tablets. Hence, tablets made from soy-protein hydrogels are ideal for colon delivery of nutraceuticals.
It was found that the microstructure (filamentous or particulate as shown in Fig. 1) had an impactable effect on the riboflavin release profile from soy protein cold-set hydrogels under gastric and intestinal conditions in the presence or absence of digestive proteases (Maltais et al., 2009). A rapid release behavior of riboflavin was reported for both types of gels at pH = 7.5 compared to pH = 1.2 in the absence of digestive enzymes due to the minimal swelling of gels in the simulated gastric fluid. Nevertheless, a little after the beginning of the dissolution test, the release of riboflavin was faster from particulate hydrogels than filamentous counterparts owing to their higher rate of large pores. The release profile of riboflavin in the gastric environment with pepsin was similar to enzyme-free mode. After 6 h digestion with pancreatin, the liberation of riboflavin reached to 80–90% compared to 26–33% for pancreatin-free simulated intestinal media. All in all, soy protein hydrogels with particulate microstructure are considered to degrade mostly in the upper part of small intestine unlike the filamentous ones which are effective in colon-specific delivery.
Hu et al. (2015) fabricated riboflavin-loaded transglutaminase-induced soy protein hydrogels from high magnitude ultrasound-treated soy protein isolate. Ultrasound treatment resulted in increasing the aggregates size of cross-linked proteins as well as the hydrophobicity of the transglutaminase-induced gels. In addition, the ultrasound treatment enhanced both the gelation yield and entrapment efficiency and declined the gastrointestinal degradation and therefore, a long-term release of riboflavin was obtained.
Recently, utilization of soy protein-based hybrid hydrogels has found its place in drug delivery practices. These types of hydrogels (blends of natural and synthetic polymers) are ideal candidates in pharmaceutical and biomedical fields since they have the advantages of both natural, (renewability, biodegradability and biocompatibility) and synthetic (stimuli-responsive capability) polymers as well as their tissue-like properties (Liu, Cui, and Liao, 2014;; Liu, Cui, Wu et al., 2014). Bovine serum albumin was loaded within the hydrogel matrix as a model drug and the in vitro release behavior of drug-loaded hydrogel was investigated at buffer solution with pH 7.4 at 37 °C and mild condition of stirring. Rapid release rate was observed for proposed hydrogels with a Fickian diffusional release mode owing to their high porous structures. The release of BSA from soy protein-poly (N- isopropylacrylamide-co-sodium acrylate) mixed hydrogel as a pHand temperature-responsive interpenetrating polymer network at different pHs and temperatures was studied by Liu, Cui, and Liao (2014). At constant temperature of 37 °C, a faster release for BSA at pH 7.4 was reported compared to pH 1.2 which was owing to the more expanded structure of samples at pH 7.4 caused by the electrostatic repulsion between –COO– groups. Moreover, the BSA release was faster at lower temperatures (at 25 °C compared to 37 °C) at the same pH of 7.4. This higher release rate was ascribed to the polymer chain relaxation at 25 °C and hydrophobic effects at 37 °C. In another investigation Liu, Cui, Yin, and Ma (2009), the hybrid hydrogel from soy protein and poly (acrylic acid), a highly pH-sensitive polymer, was used for colon sitespecific delivery of a model drug (bovine serum albumin). The results of in vitro release experiments of BSA showed a higher release at colonic fluid with diffusion and relaxation controlled mechanism in comparison with gastric fluid. The authors also observed a lower release for BSA at pH 7.4 and 37 °C with an increase in the soy protein content due to the enhancing of hydrogel relaxation as a result of electrostatic repulsion effect and decrement of fixed carboxylic groups in polymer network. According to these observations, the BSA release profile from soy protein-poly(acrylic acid) hybrid hydrogel can be controlled by varying the soy protein content. Accordingly, owing to their high pH-sensitivity, soy protein-poly(acrylic acid) composite hydrogels might be considered as suitable nominees for targeted delivery of drugs and bioactive ingredients, particularly for colon site-specific delivery of peptide and protein drugs. In addition to the drug delivery, hybrid poly(ethylene glycol)-soy protein hydrogels were used for wound dressing applications (Snyders et al., 2007). The improved wound healing response of these blend hydrogels was attributed to the moist environment and ability of hydrogels to interact with low molecular weight proteins at the site of injury. In general, the soy protein-synthetic polymer based hybrid hydrogels with a good responsivity to human body might be appropriate for the controlled liberation and site-specific transfer of drugs and nutrients.

sections.heading: 5. Whey protein-based hydrogels
sections.text: Whey proteins are milk-derived proteins with superb functional, biological, and nutritional properties. The main components of whey proteins as shown in Fig. 4 are globular proteins including β-lactoglobulin, α-lactalbumin, and bovine serum albumin (Loveday, Su, Rao, Anema, & Singh, 2012). A great number of studies have reported the usage of whey protein products including whey protein isolate (WPI) and concentrate (WPC) or its components (especially β-lactoglobulin and bovine serum albumin) for the preparation of protein-based hydrogels with the aim of encasing and delivery of bioactive molecules and micronutrients (Table 2). These hydrogels can be formulated by introducing whey proteins, in their native or aggregated (fibrils and microgels) forms, individually or in combination with other materials.

sections.heading: 5.1. Hydrogels from WPI, WPC and β-lactoglobulin
sections.text:
Incorporation of bioactive ingredients into whey protein hydrogels as well as their release profile depends on different factors particularly the microstructure of hydrogel plus the properties of payloads (Jonker, Löwik, & van Hest, 2012). For example, it has been shown that the release profile of nutraceuticals from whey protein hydrogels can be modulated by means of coating with oppositely charged polysaccharides such as alginate and chitosan (Gunasekaran, Ko, & Xiao, 2007). In line with this point of view, it was reported that insulin-
loaded whey protein isolate/alginate mucoadhesive cold-set hydrogels indicated a diffusion-based release trend with a higher in vivo insulin uptake across duodenal in the rabbits as animal models (Déat-Lainé et al., 2013). In addition, in a research conducted by Reddy, Lavenant, Lefebvre, and Renard (2006) hydrated and dehydrated β-lactoglobulin gels were prepared by gelation/phase separation method in water/ ethanol mixture and the swelling behavior of gels and release profile of theophylline and sulfamethoxazole, two model drugs, were investigated. Irrespective of the hydration state of gels, swelling in water was highest in comparison with other solvents including water/ethanol, phosphate buffer solution, phosphate buffer with dithiothreitol or urea, NaCl solution and NaCl-HCl buffer due to the superiority of solventsolute interactions rather than solute-solute counterparts. In vitro studies at pH 7.8 and 1.2 demonstrated Fickian and diffusion release modes, respectively for hydrated and dehydrated gels which can be interpreted through the swelling and structural rearrangements of gel matrix during hydration and dehydration procedures.
Efficient delivery systems should be able to modulate the intestinal absorption of vitamins and nutrients. It was reported by Somchue, Sermsri, Shiowatana, and Siripinyanond (2009) that approximately 86% of the encapsulated α-tocopherol in α-tocopherol-loaded salt-induced β-lactoglobulin gels was released after 2.0 h of in vitro digestion at simulated gastric fluid, but when the gels were coated with sodium alginate, owing to its rigidity and hard swelling in gastric condition, the release rate reduced in simulated gastric fluid and enhanced at the intestinal environment. Whey protein isolate thermally induced hydrogels also were used for encapsulation of anthocyanin-rich bilberry extract and showed a Fickian diffusion based release mechanism for bioactive phenolic compounds at simulated gastric fluid (Betz & Kulozik, 2011).
Niosomes are non-ionic surfactant vesicles which have found great applicability in pharmaceutical, nutraceutical, and cosmetic areas owing to their superb characteristics for encapsulation and delivery of active materials Abaee and Madadlou (2016) fabricated α-tocopherolloaded niosomes embedded in cold-set whey protein hydrogels (Fig. 5). Whey proteins edible hydrogels are also ideal candidates for delivery of minerals. In addition to calcium and sodium ions which are of utmost importance in cold-gelation of proteins, other essential dietary elements can be used for gelation of proteins with the aim of improvement of hydrogel nutrient dense. For instance, whey protein hydrogels made with iron can be considered as efficient delivery vehicles since the presence of amino acids enhances the bioavailability of iron ions. Iron ion concentration is a determinative factor in the mechanism of gelation; gels prepared by low concentrations of the ion had filamentous microstructure and those prepared at high ratios of iron/protein were composed of randomly aggregated particles (Remondetto et al., 2002). Incorporation of ascorbate in Fe2+ cold-set whey protein gel particles can increase the in vitro bio-accessibility of Fe2+ due to the chelating function of ascorbate for ferric ions and also results in the reduction of iron oxidation in whey protein media (Martin & De Jong, 2012a). Heat treatment of protein solution can also affect the properties of ion-encased whey protein cold-set gels. Martin and De Jong (2012b) studied the effect of protein heat treatment (mild, intermediate, and severe) conditions on the iron encapsulation efficiency of whey protein cold-set gel. At natural pH cold-set gel samples which were prepared from whey protein solution with intermediate heating condition (85 °C, 3 h and pH = 3.35) showed a higher iron release compared to mild (85 °C, 30 min and pH = 7.0) and severe (pH = 2.0, 80 °C for extended period) counterparts likely due to the formation of different structural entities as a function of heating condition. However, at acidic pH, no significant difference was observed between samples for iron release. Similar to the soy proteins, the microstructure of whey protein hydrogel (filamentous versus particulate) can modify the liberation properties of the payloads. In this regard, Remondetto, Beyssac, and Subirade (2004) studied the in vitro release of iron from β-lactoglobulin hydrogels in terms of their architecture. Gels were prepared using different concentrations of Fe2+ (10 or 30 mM) and release of iron was studied under simulated gastrointestinal conditions in the presence of pepsin (pH = 1.2) and pancreatin (pH = 7.5). The iron release in simulated gastrointestinal conditions was greatly dependent to the gel microstructure and it was higher for filamentous networks than particulate ones during the intestinal phase of simulated digestion. Dramatic differences which were recognized between various hydrogels in the term of iron release at gastrointestinal tract conditions were attributed to the
gel pore size, protein net charge, and also interaction between gels and iron. The authors also used Caco-2 system (originated from human colorectal carcinoma) to estimate intestinal absorption of iron and reported a higher intracellular iron absorption for filamentous gels in comparison with particulate ones due to the locating of iron ions at the outer surface of the linear aggregates. Accordingly, filamentous gels can be considered as more appropriate candidates for site-specific controlled delivery of iron due to the fact that iron should be liberated as close as possible to intestinal wall as its absorption window.
It was also investigated that the swelling property of hydrogels made with globular proteins such as egg white, soy, and whey proteins was strongly dependent on the microstructure (stranded or particulate) of gels (Mercadé-Prieto, Zhao, Zhang, & Chen, 2016; Li, Zhao, Chen, &Mercadé-Prieto, 2016; Li, Chen, &Mercadé-Prieto, 2017). Results of the above-mentioned studies suggested that globular-protein based hydrogels with a particulate microstructure only swell when interactions within and/or between particulates are destroyed, whereas the flexibility of strands allows the stranded hydrogels to swell and shrink easily without the changing of strands actual size. Swelling ability is an important property for drug/nutraceutical delivery systems such as hydrogels. Swelling is a key factor in swelling-controlled release systems like pH-sensitive hydrogels which provide an appropriate cargo-diffusion pathway by a pore mechanism (Fan et al., 2017; Yin, Yang, & Xu, 2001). Besides, swelling behavior can affect the erosioncontrolled delivery systems by facilitating the diffusion of digestive enzymes through the network (Maltais et al., 2010). Recently, it was also investigated that cross-linking by citric acid was effective on the swelling behavior of caffeine-loaded whey protein heat-set hydrogels. Cross-linking decreased the swelling ratio of hydrogels because the cross-linked hydrogel samples had a less porous microstructure and interconnected networks (Zand-Rajabi &Madadlou, 2016).
Whey proteins can be mixed with other edible materials in order to obtain gels with modified characteristics. For instance, honey can be added to whey protein solution and this mixture can form gel network as a result of heating. With respect to the healing property of honey in the skin burns and its sweetness, these types of hydrogels can be used for wound healing applications in the biomedical sector as well as for delivery of nutraceuticals with a bitter taste (Yamul & Lupano, 2003). It has been shown by differential scanning calorimetric experiments that honey can increase the apparent transition temperature for protein denaturation at all pH values due to the ability of sugars to increase the surface free energy between water and a hydrophobic surface such as unfolded patches of whey proteins. The presence of honey can also improve the water holding capacity of hydrogels by providing a more
homogeneous microstructure with smaller pore sizes and finally a lower cohesiveness and relaxation time (Yamul & Lupano, 2003). Sucrose is another compound which its influence on whey protein gels has been studied. According to the ability of sucrose to form hydrogen bonds with water and subsequently increasing the viscosity, a more homogeneous structure with smaller pores, higher water holding capacity and hardness is expected to be formed for whey protein-sucrose mixed gels (Yamul, Galmarini, Lupano, & Zamora, 2013).
In another study in the field of mixed whey protein hydrogels, Paraskevopoulou, Amvrosiadou, Biliaderis, and Kiosseoglou (2014) characterized the rheological behavior and volatile compounds of heatset WPI-egg yolk mixed gels. Incorporation of egg yolk or its plasma into WPI solution, increased the storage and elastic modulus of mixed gels because of interaction between egg lipoproteins and whey proteins especially β-lactoglobulin and also void spaces filling ability of LDL micelles. Analyzing of gels volatile compounds also surprisingly showed that butanoic acid (unpleasant cheesy/rancid odor) was not detectable in the egg-whey mixed gels in comparison with WPI counterpart. Polysaccharide (xanthan gum, pectin and gum tragacanth) blended heat-set whey protein isolate hydrogels also were successfully used to encapsulate the black carrot extract (Ozel, Cikrikci, Aydin, & Oztop, 2017).

sections.heading: 5.2. Hydrogels from bovine serum albumin
sections.text:
In addition to the β-lactoglobulin, another important globular protein, bovine serum albumin, has the potential to form hydrogels. Donato, Garnier, Doublier, and Nicolai (2005) studied the effect of mono- and divalent salts (NaCl and CaCl2) concentration on the structure of heat-induced bovine serum albumin gels at pH = 7.0. They reported that repulsive forces were reduced at high salt levels and CaCl2 was more efficient than NaCl at the same ionic strength in reducing these interactions. CaCl2-madiated gelation of denatured filamentous BSA pre-aggregates which were produced by heating (90 °C for 90 min) of protein aqueous solutions at pH = 7.0 were examined (Wu, Arosio, Podolskaya, Wei, &Morbidelli, 2012). Transparent filamentous gels in both low and high concentrations of CaCl2 were generated by means of hydration processes, while opaque gels were noticeable at intermediate usage of salt.
pH-sensitive hydrogels can be generated from methacrylate derivatized BSA and methacrylic acid sodium salt by means of free radical polymerization. These classes of hydrogels are ideal for intestinal delivery of orally administered acidic drugs such as diflunisal and βpropranolol (Iemma et al., 2006). As potentially injectable drug delivery systems, thermoresponsive hydrogels with sol-gel transition at body temperature (between 37 and 40 °C) can be produced from BSA esterified with low molecular weight polyethylene glycol. BSA-PEG gels possess sustained release characteristics and show enhanced biodegradability in comparison with BSA hydrogels (Wang, BuschleDiller, &Wu, 2014). Tada, Tanabe, Tachibana, and Yamauchi (2005) prepared hydrogels from vinylated BSA through the copolymerization with acrylamide by applying ammonium persulfate (APS) and TEMED (N,N,N′, N′-tetramethylenediamine). Hydrogel samples were loaded with sodium benzoate and salicylic acid as model drugs and their release was studied in distilled water at room temperature. Release of salicylic acid from vinylated BSA-acrylamide hydrogels into distilled water was higher than sodium benzoate. Finally, the liberation of salicylic acid was influenced greatly by the drug binding to BSA, while in the case of sodium benzoate; the release rate scaled directly with the swelling ratio.

sections.heading: 5.3. Hydrogels from aggregated forms of whey proteins
sections.text:
Heating of whey proteins, especially β-lactoglobulin, at acidic conditions (typically 2.0) together with low ionic strengths, leads to formation of long straight fibrils with micrometric length, nanometric
thickness, and multi-stranded cross-β structure. It has been found that low-calorie products and delivery systems such as hydrogels at very low concentration of proteins can be fabricated using whey protein nanofibrils (Mohammadian &Madadlou, 2016a). Veerman et al. (2003) produced cold-set gels from β-lactoglobulin fibrils at a considerably lower critical percolation concentration in comparison with conventional cold- and heat-set gelation methods. The gelation behavior of whey protein nanofibrils at very low protein concentration are related to their high aspect ratio and anisotropic dimensions (Kroes-Nijboer, Venema, & van der Linden, 2012). Soft viscoelastic gels with zero ash content were prepared from whey protein nanofibrils by dialyzing against different concentration of CaCl2 without direct increment of nanofibril solution pH which can be a potential nominee for conveying bioactive molecules that are sensitive to ions for example, those drugs that show reduced therapeutic impact owing to binding with ions (Farjami, Madadlou, & Labbafi, 2016).
In addition to better functional properties, a higher susceptibility to in vitro pepsin digestion was reported for β-lactoglobulin fibrils which were formed by prolonged heating at pH 2.0 in comparison with sample that was heated at pH = 7.4 and same conditions (Bateman, Ye, & Singh, 2010). Moreover, a complete proteolysis of WPI fibrils after 3.0 h was observed with pancreatin at pH 7.5 (Lassé et al., 2016). Serfert et al. (2014) used β-lactoglobulin fibril-based microcapsules for retention of fish oil and reported higher microencapsulation efficiency and lower oxidative deterioration for fibril-based system compared to native WPI counterparts due to its better interfacial barrier property. In line with this research, Mohammadian and Madadlou (2016a) noticed that fibrillation augmented the antioxidant activity of WPI. This higher antioxidant activity was ascribed to the conformational modification and degradation of proteins by heat and acid during fibrillation process. These scholars also made cold-set hydrogels of whey protein nanofibrils with different divalent cations including calcium, manganese, and zinc at low protein concentration (54 mg mL−1) and claimed that resulting hydrogels have remarkable mechanical strength and significant susceptibility to gastric digestion and can be used as delivery systems for drugs and nutraceuticals which need acidic activation for the stomach adenomas treatment (Mohammadian &Madadlou, 2016b). To sum up, it is suggested that whey protein nanofibril-based hydrogels can have a plethora of food applications especially in the delivery of nutraceuticals owing to their improved functional, nutritional, and antioxidant promoting features.
Whey hydrogels were also made from microgels, another form of whey protein aggregates. Heating of whey protein solution at pH range of 5.7–5.9 results in the formation of spherical shape aggregates with a low polydispersity index and dimension of several hundred nanometers known as microgels (Donato, Kolodziejcyk, & Rouvet, 2011). Whey protein microgels can be used for producing whey protein gels. Farjami et al. (2015) fabricated pre and post-cross-linked microgels using citric acid and employed them as building blocks of protein hydrogels and observed that cross-linking is the key factor in the size reduction of formed microgels. Gels prepared from post-cross-linked microgels were firmer and had higher water retention compared with typical or precross-linked microgels due likely to the existence of a higher number of carboxyl residues in the structure of the pre-cross-linked microgels. Egan et al. (2014) analyzed the capability of calcium-mediated cold-set whey protein microgels for using as pH-sensitive immobilization for charged bioactives including two model peptides; Trp-Glu-Asn-Gly-Glu and Lys-His-Ile-Gln-Lys. Results of the aforementioned study indicated that cold-set whey protein microgels are proper smart delivery vehicles, in which uptake and liberation of bioactives are facilitated by environmental pH alteration which affects the adherence of peptides with microgels by altering their ionic profile and hydrophobic status.

sections.heading: 5.4. Whey protein aerated hydrogels
sections.text:
Incorporating of gas bubbles into food matrix may result in a
product with desirable sensory properties. Many food products such as bread, cakes, aerated chocolate bars and meringue, and whipped cream contain air bubbles as their architecture. Aerated hydrogels are a class of gels with both entrapped air bubbles and water. These gels may find applicability in reduced calorie food formulations and can be used as vectors for flavors and nutraceuticals (Zúñiga & Aguilera, 2008). Whey proteins have a great ability for gelation, thus, investigation of the properties of aerated gels obtained from these proteins is of considerable interest. Textural properties, gas hold up, and average bubble size of aerated whey protein heat set gels is under control by the heating temperature of protein admix (Orrego, Troncoso, & Zúñiga, 2015). The aerated gel matrices can expand the spectrum of release mechanisms allowing the development of new product and the creation of engineered complex structures. Furthermore, it has been proved that aroma release from aerated gel is faster than conventional gel as well as having a higher storage and loss moduli (Tomczynska-Mleko, 2009). Whey protein cold-set aerated gels were also prepared using a simultaneous gelation and aeration process. Gels with high syneresis and large bubbles were obtained at higher calcium ion extent (30 mM) and fine-stranded gels with tiny bubble size were obtained at 20 mM calcium ion concentrations which demonstrated great stability. Besides, bubble size of the gels was not constant at different protein concentrations and pH (ToMczyńska-Mleko, 2013).
One approach in engineering oral controlled drug delivery systems is using floating drug delivery systems which may increase the bioavailability of the encased drug through increasing the retention time of the drug in the stomach. Having a bulk density lower than gastric fluids, these superb vectors remain buoyant in stomach allowing the drug to exert a desired release rate (Singh & Kim, 2000). When orally administered, aerated gels float in the stomach and will not penetrate to the lower intestinal tract before they are wholly disintegrated. Hence, ion-induced whey protein aerated gels are promising vehicles for supplementation of the human body with essential microelements such as Fe2+ and Mg2+ (Tomczyńska-Mleko &Mleko, 2014). It should be noted that in ion-induced aerated gels, the structure of the obtained gel surface scales directly with the character and extent of added salt (Tomczyńska-Mleko, Terpiłowski, Mleko, Kwiatkowski, & KaweckaRadomska, 2015).

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: Hydrogels from soy and whey globular proteins are efficient vehicles to entrap, shield and deliver a variety of nutraceuticals and bioactive components in the food and pharmaceutical sectors due to their superb features. Different factors affect the mechanical, microstructural, and textural attributes of these hydrogels as well as their cargo liberation behavior. As the subject of this review, hydrogels from soy and whey proteins can be used as site-specific delivery networks in the gastrointestinal tract with respect to their responsivity to pH and digestive enzymes. Recently, mixed and aerated hydrogels along with hydrogels emanated from aggregated types of globular proteins were also developed to deliver bioactive components. However, it seems that much more research on hydrogels and its aerated form on the basis of aggregated types of whey and soy globular proteins should be conducted with respect to their outstanding characteristics such as gelationat lower concentrations which results in the formulation of lowcalorie delivery systems. Moreover, it seems that the lack of in vivo trials is a limitation of many included studies and should be a focus for the future.

metadata.abstractText: Background: Bioactive molecules are mostly amenable to degradation at processing, storage, and harsh digestion conditions. Hence, high-throughput encapsulation bodies must be designed in a way to protect them from destructive circumstances and to enhance their bioavailability. Scope and approach: This review article focuses on versatile mechanisms for gelation of globular proteins and highlights the current studies on whey and soy protein hydrogels as two key animal and herbal proteins used in fabricating coating materials. Moreover, different categories of hydrogels, such as aerated hydrogels, hydrogels made from aggregated forms of proteins, hydrogels originated from food-grade materials, and hydrogels with nano scale dimensions are discussed. Key findings and conclusions: The gelation and particulation method have dramatic effects on the liberation features as well as the bioactivity of the wrapped ingredients. Therefore, different approaches are needed to be considered in order to increase the bioavailability of nutraceuticals and drugs accommodated within protein hydrogels. Accordingly, there is a growing trend for developing innovative modes of gelation and immobilizing bioactive materials into the hydrogel network.
